items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Education Code Section 76140 requires each district to establish its non-resident tuition for the subsequent fiscal year by February 1.  The non-resident tuition fee is composed of two parts: the tuition fee and an assessment for capital outlay.
	 
For 2014/15, the base rate was set at the district rate of $132. The capital outlay rate was set at $17, for a total of $149 per quarter unit (applicable to all non-resident students).
	 
For 2015/16, the statewide rate is $133 per quarter unit compared to the district rate of $135 as per the calculations on page 1 of the attached worksheet. Under these circumstances, the district has the following options:
	 
1. Set the rate at the statewide average rate of $133 (plus capital)
	 
2. Set the rate at the district average rate of $135 (plus capital)
	 
3. Option 3, as specified under Education Code Section 76140, cannot be exercised as FHDA enrollment in non-credit courses is below 10%
	 
4. Set the rate to equal the rate of a contiguous district (plus capital)
	 
5. No more than district average cost, no less than the state average cost (plus capital)
	 
6. Set the rate at ‘highest years statewide average tuition.’ This rate is calculated to be $133 per quarter unit (plus capital)
	 
7. Set the rate at no greater than the 2013/14 average non-resident tuition fee of public community colleges in a minimum of 12 states comparable to California in cost of living. This average is calculated to be $253 per quarter unit (plus capital)
	 
Upon analysis of these options, and in discussion with the Dean of International Programs, it is recommended that the base rate be set at $135 (Option 2) for 2015/16, or $3 more than in 2014/15.
	 
The 2015/16 non-resident student capital outlay fee should not exceed the lesser of $23 per quarter unit (see calculation on page 2 of the attached worksheet) or 50% of the adopted 2014/15 nonresident tuition fee of $132, or $66.  We are recommending that the capital outlay fee for 2015/16 be set at $17, the same as for 2014/15.  Note: Since fiscal year 2010/11, AB 947 amended EC 76141 to enable community college districts to charge all non-resident students a capital outlay fee, not only those students who were both citizens and residents of a foreign country.
	 
In summary, the rate for all non-resident students will be $135 base rate plus $17 capital rate for a total of $152 per quarter unit, representing a $3 increase over the 2014/15 rate.
	 
Submitted by:
 Kevin McElroy, Vice Chancellor, Business Services, x6202
Additional contact names:
 Joni Hayes, Director, Budget Operations, x6261
Is backup provided?
 Yes
items.item_recommendation: It is recommended that the Board approve the base rate of $135/quarter unit and the capital outlay rate of $17/quarter unit for a total of $152/unit for all non-resident students for the 2015/16 fiscal year.

Background and Analysis:
	 
The District has been notified by CalSTRS that CalSTRS retirees may not serve in CalPERS eligible positions that are part of a school. This impacts Patricia James, the Online Education Initiative (OEI) Executive Director.  She is a current CalSTRS retiree, and her position as OEI Executive Director is a CalPERS eligible position.  The District was not made aware of this restriction by CalSTRS until after Ms. James was employed by the District.
	The Foundation for California Community Colleges (FCCC) has agreed to assist the District with Ms. James' continued employment as the OEI Executive Director.  Effective January 1, 2015, the FCCC will employ Ms. James, and the District will contract with the FCCC for her services. Subsequently, Ms. James will resign her position with the District but will continue to provide leadership to the OEI as the Executive Director in an identical manner.  As the FCCC is not a school, the CalSTRS restriction on CalPERS employment is not applicable.
	 
Submitted by:
 Joe Moreau, Vice Chancellor, Technology, x6120
Additional contact names:
					 
Is backup provided?
 Yes

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Foothill College desires to increase enrollment and foster community awareness of its educational offerings through continued media advertisements in the local Bay Area.  The cost of advertising ranges from $150,000 to $200,000 per year, depending on actual advertisement outreach efforts. Therefore, Purchasing Services staff worked with the Foothill College Marketing & Public Relations Department to develop a request for proposals and a scope of work for services required to obtain these services.
	 
Request for Proposal (RFP) #1716 was advertised in the San Jose Post Record on October 17 and October 24, 2014.  The RFP was also sent to six (6) vendors and was posted on “BidNet” at www.govbids.com. RFP’s were due on November 12, 2014 and two vendors submitted a response, Ad Age Broadcast Network and SkoolLive.  Purchasing Services staff and Andrea Hanstein, Foothill College Director of Marketing & Public Relations evaluated the responses. Of the two responses, SkoolLive did not respond directly to all of the requirements and needs described in the RFP.  The response from Ad Age was complete and thorough and meets the needs of the College. Ad Age currently provides the same services to Foothill College and other higher education institutions in the Bay Area such as San Mateo CCD and West Valley Mission CCD.
	 
Submitted by:
  Pam Grey, Director of Purchasing Services, x 6166
Additional contact names:
  Andrea Hanstein – x7645, Gina Bailey – x6165

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The Board of Governors of the California Community Colleges awarded a competitive grant to a partnership of the Foothill-De Anza and Butte Glenn community college districts to launch Governor Jerry Brown’s groundbreaking Online Education Initiative (OEI) for the state of California.  The goal of the initiative is to increase the number of California students who obtain associate degrees and transfer to four-year institutions. Online tutoring services is a key component of this initiative and is anticipated to improve student course success rates.
	 
In accordance with the California Public Contract Code (PCC) Section 20651(a) through (d), only the governing board may authorize award of purchase orders that exceed the legally mandated bid threshold, and the board must award the orders to the lowest responsible bidder or reject all bids.  However, in lieu of the district conducting its own bid process, Public Contract Code (PCC) section 20652 provides that community college districts may utilize contracts that have been awarded by other public entities. 
	 
As a lead agency of the OEI grant, Foothill-De Anza and the OEI Steering Committee will guide the success of the program for online tutoring.  Representatives from Foothill-De Anza, the OEI Steering Committee, and educators throughout the state sought the expertise of the Foundation for California Community Colleges to develop an RFP to secure online tutoring services and infrastructure in support of the OEI initiative.  Initial services will roll out to eight (8) colleges in Spring 2015 to pilot the program.  
	 
The Foundation for California Community Colleges awarded RFP #14-001 which is a piggybackable contract for an online tutoring service infrastructure and fee structure slated to help improve student course success rates in support of the OEI initiative; the contract is valid for one and one-half years with an option to renew for up to three additional years. This award was the result of a competitive, RFP process conducted in accordance with the California Public Contract Code.
	 
The OEI grant will fund up to $2.5 million to support the OEI online tutoring activities over the next four and one half years.
	 
Submitted by:
					  Pam Grey, Director of Purchasing Services, x 6166
Additional contact names:
					  Joe Moreau, Pat James, Gina Bailey
Is backup provided?
					  Yes

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
This project will replace the existing chiller, chilled water pumps, motors, and controls for the chilled water cooling system at the De Anza College Science Center buildings. The project scope of work will also include the Contractor’s coordination with the temporary chiller vendor as well as the installation and removal of temporary piping, valves, and support components that will complete the temporary chiller connections during the project. Salas O’Brien prepared the design and the bid specifications for the work.
	 
The bid was legally advertised to contractors on November 7 and November 14, 2014. The “Invitation to Bid” was also sent to nine (9) builder’s exchanges and advertised in the Daily Pacific Builder as well as posted on “BidNet” at www.govbids.com.  Bids were publicly opened and read on December 11, 2014, in the Purchasing Services office. Four (4) contractors submitted bids. Bid results are below:
BID RESULTS
Contractor
Base Bid 
Proposal Amount
Pullman Construction Inc.
$625,000
Environmental Systems Inc. of Northern California
$639,000
Integra Construction Services Inc.
$699,973
Lyles Mechanical Co.
$869,700
	 
The Bid Proposal submitted by the apparent low bidder, Pullman Construction Inc. (Pullman), was incomplete in that the fields that required the contractor’s license classification number and expiration date as defined in Paragraph 4 of the bid form were left blank. Purchasing staff immediately confirmed that Pullman’s contractor’s license was valid on the California Contractor’s State License Board website and requested that Pullman complete the form and resubmit. It is the opinion of the Director of Purchasing Services, Pam Grey, that this minor omission and the immediate correction can be waived as a minor irregularity. The contract documents state “the District reserves the right to reject any or all Bid Proposals or to waive any irregularities or informalities in any Bid Proposal or in the bidding.” 
	 
Furthermore, Pullman confirmed that its bid price of $625,000 is true and accurate for the work as specified and it confirmed that all first tier subcontractors were listed. Pullman Construction successfully performed work at the Media and Learning Center building at De Anza College for its chilled water production system. 
	 
The construction estimate for the repair was $525,000 - $575,000, excluding a $50,000 allowance for unforeseen conditions and infrastructure for a temporary chiller. The bid price of $625,000 that includes the allowances is within the estimated value and will be paid for by a combination of State of California Block Grant and Proposition 39 funds. 
	 
Submitted by:
  Director of Purchasing Services, Pam Grey 
Additional contact names:
  Jennifer Mahato, Tom Armstrong, Steve Kitchen, Gina Bailey 
Is backup provided?
  No
items.item_recommendation: Waive the minor omission in the Bid Proposal as a minor irregularity and authorize the Director of Purchasing Services, Pam Grey, to award a contract pursuant to Bid Document 1698 – Science Center Chiller Replacement at De Anza College in the amount of $625,000 to Pullman Construction, Inc.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Information was provided to the Board of Trustees on December 7, 2009, and January 19, 2010, concerning the use of a Lease-Leaseback construction procurement process for Measure C projects. The information included a discussion of the legal aspects of the process as well as the likely risks and benefits associated with construction using the authority provided under the Education Code section 81335. On August 31, 2010, a default judgment was issued by the Santa Clara County Superior Court which confirmed the validity of the use of this procurement process. Since that time the Board has approved the use of Lease-Leaseback procurement for several projects: the Media and Learning Center, the Physical Sciences & Engineering Center, the District Data Center, the Advanced Technology Center and the L-7 Renovation.
	 
The procurement process for this project will be consistent with the process used for previously-approved projects, and it will include the same key decision/Board approval steps. The Board will be requested to review and approve key decisions and actions in the procurement process over a period of time. Target dates for key actions associated with the project are as follows:
April, 2015 - Approval of the Lease-Leaseback contractor based upon a Request for Qualifications and Request for Proposals process
April, 2015 - Award of a pre-construction services agreement for the Lease- Leaseback contractor
May, 2015 - Approval of a Site Lease and a Facilities Lease with the Lease- Leaseback contractor including a guaranteed maximum price for building renovation based on DSA-approved plans and Specifications
Mid-May, 2015 - Construction commences on the Campus Drive

Background and Analysis:
	 
On December 10, 2012, the Board authorized award of a Preconstruction Services Agreement to Kitchell CEM, Inc. (Kitchell) based upon the recommendation of the Selection Committee. The Preconstruction Services Agreement required Kitchell to prequalify subcontractors, obtain competitive bids from subcontractors, develop a Guaranteed Maximum Price (GMP) to construct the project, and develop a Preliminary Construction Schedule.  On April 7, 2014 the Board of Trustees approved execution of the Site Lease and the Facilities Lease for the Project, which included a GMP for only the 3600 Swing Space Build Out Phase of the project. Kitchell has completed that phase of work for the amount of the GMP.  
	 
This Amendment modifies the Facilities Lease to include a GMP for a Building 3500 Renovation Phase of the Project in the amount of $10,495,749. This phase includes the remodel of existing library building 3500.  Improvements include: structural, mechanical, electrical, and telecom system upgrades, roof replacement, and new interior finishes throughout.
	 
During construction of this Building 3500 Renovation Phase a GMP for the following Building 3600 Renovation Phase will be developed by Kitchell CEM. A final Amendment to the Facilities Lease will be brought to the Board of Trustees that will include the GMP for that phase and the final cost for all phases. The construction budget for all Project phases is $10,900,000. The Library & ISC project is funded by Measure C.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
An easement to the City of Sunnyvale allows an existing city-owned sanitary sewer line to run through the parcel of the former Onizuka Air Force Station land that now belongs to the District.  The sewer is undersized and in poor condition and has been identified for replacement in the City’s utility master plan, but the City’s project to replace the sewer is scheduled to take place after the Education Center has been built. 
	 
In order to avoid future disruption to the Education Center operations and undue cost to the City, the District and the City have reached an agreement to allow the District to replace the sewer as part of its site improvements, with the cost of the work being reimbursed to the District by the City.
	 
This agreement is similar to the Memorandum of Agreement that enabled the District to demolish City buildings with reimbursement by the City, as approved by the Board of Trustees on May 13, 2003.  Repayment by the City for design and construction cost is due to the District upon acceptance of the work.

Background and Analysis:
	 
On October 3, 2011, a Memorandum of Agreement with the City of Sunnyvale (City) was approved by the Board of Trustees that defined the terms and conditions for the City to include the District’s project as part of the redevelopment plan for the reuse of the Onizuka Air Force Station property.  That Agreement required the District to make street frontage improvements and to dedicate land for the related rights-of-way.  In addition, the Education Center project involves extensions and modifications to City utilities to serve the building, requiring utility easements to be granted to the City, and requiring permits from the City.
	 
This Improvement Agreement requires the District to provide bonds to the City to ensure that the utility and street improvements are completed, and provides for payment to the City for utility connections and related plan review and inspections, in the amount of $66,230.75.
	 
Two related agreements are need to establish easements related to this construction.  Those agreements are the subject of a separate Agenda Item at this meeting of the Board.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Public Access Deed:
	 
The parcel of land deeded to the District through the federal public benefit conveyance includes the eastern half of Innovation Way; the District, not the City of Sunnyvale, owns the street in front of the Education Center.  In order to maintain the street as a public way, the District will record a Public Access Easement Deed with Santa Clara County that allows public use of the street from the center line of Innovation Way to the back of the sidewalk.  This Deed is an attachment to the Improvement Maintenance Agreement.
	 
Improvement Maintenance Agreement:
	 
Because the District owns the street, it is responsible for its operation and maintenance.  This agreement includes requirements for the repair, maintenance and operation of the street within the public access easement described above.  In summary, the District is required to maintain street pavement and signage, sidewalks, street lighting, street frontage landscaping, and private utilities within the area.  The District is bound to maintain insurance of its land within the street easement.
	 
The attached backup documents do not include some exhibit drawings which were still being prepared at board agenda deadline.
